Step 4 -  Section 512(c)(1) (21 U.S.C. 360b(c)(1)) is amended to allow the applicant to notify the Secretary of an impasse in the review process, leading to a referral of the disputed issue for resolution. The Secretary can refer a disputed issue to a scientific advisory panel or a mediator for resolution. The committee or person must submit recommendations within 60 days of the referral. The Secretary may refer a disputed issue to a scientific advisory panel or mediator for resolution within 60 days. The Secretary must confirm or modify the recommendations within 30 days, with reasons provided. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to scientific advisory panels under this provision. SEC. 204 amends Section 512(d)(1)(F) regarding drug residues. SEC. 205 introduces regulations for veterinary feed directive drugs. Sec. 504 outlines the requirements for veterinary feed directive drugs, stating that they must be used under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian. A lawful veterinary feed directive must contain specific information as required by the Secretary and comply with certain conditions and indications. The distribution and use of animal feed with veterinary feed directive drugs must comply with specified conditions and indications. Those involved must maintain a copy of the directive for each feed, except in cases of further distribution where a written acknowledgement is required to ensure compliance. "Persons distributing animal feed with veterinary feed directive drugs must maintain records and allow access for verification upon request. Failure to notify the Secretary before distributing such feed is considered misbranding. Misbranding occurs if the labeling lacks a cautionary statement." The labeling of drugs must include cautionary statements as prescribed by the Secretary. Animal feed with veterinary drugs must be used under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian. In subsection (a)(2)(C), distribution and holding requirements are added. In subsection (m)(4)(B)(i), references to section 504(a)(3)(A) and section 504(a)(3)(B) are included. Section 301(e) (21 U.S.C. 331(e)) is amended to include section 504 in labeling requirements.
